channel.title: Fractals
channel.description:
http://www.miqel.com/fractals_math_patterns/visual-math-natural-fractals.html
The geometry of Fractals brings us a new appreciation for the natural world and the patterns we observe in it. Many things previously called chaos are now known to follow subtle subtle fractal laws of behavior. So many things turned out to be fractal that the word "chaos" itself (in operational science) had redefined, or actually for the FIRST time Formally Defined as following inherently unpredictable yet generally deterministic rules based on nonlinear iterative equations. Fractals are unpredictable in specific details yet deterministic when viewed as a total pattern - in many ways this reflects what we observe in the small details & total pattern of life in all it's physical and mental varieties, too .... FRACTAL FERN: One very simple way to understand fractals and the meaning of "lteration" is to examine a simple recursive operation that produces a fractal fern thru a "chaos game' of generating random numbers and then placing them on a grid. After a few dozen repetitions or ITERATIONS the shape we would recognize as a Perfect Fern appears from the abstract world of math. How and Why can this be? The answer to why is that it Simply IS - and it's quite surprising too! Answering How is that nature always follows the simplest & most efficient path. Fractals are maps of the simplest paths sliding up the scale of Dimensions (from 2-D to 3-D and so on). So maybe it's simply an artifact of nature's elegance that we find exact correspondences between these inherently existing mathematical forms and natural patterns, and even living creatures of many types. Fractals in nature are ubiquitous - clouds, plants, galaxies, shells and more.
[img]http://www.miqel.com/images_1/fractal_math_patterns/simple-fractal/ferns.jpg[/img] Thoughts?

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Ah, I see. Perhaps I thought of it the way I did because I’m a fractal artist and only think of iterations of patterns, and not objects being within objects.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“rip4d, post:16, topic:450326”][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=553221.msg4055037#msg4055037 date=1342853953]
The universe is a fractal.
[/quote]How so? There isn’t any repeating pattern as far as I can tell; it seems more of a tier list than anything.

Universe
v
Galaxy
v
Planetary System
V
Planet

You really can’t delve further as there isn’t anything else that can be iterated and placed in that list. It’s more similar to a living organism (organism, body system, organ, tissue, cell) than a fractal.[/quote]
If you look at the universe as a sphere, then when you go closer to an galaxy you see more spheres. Solar systems look like spheres for a distance but contain several new sphere or planets. Then you have the moons, and the moon’s moons.

Read full topic

Universe
v
Galaxy
v
Planetary System
V
Planet

You really can’t delve further as there isn’t anything else that can be iterated and placed in that list. It’s more similar to a living organism (organism, body system, organ, tissue, cell) than a fractal.

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:13, topic:450326”][quote author=rip4d link=topic=553221.msg4054628#msg4054628 date=1342825230]
A fractal is an infinitely repeating pattern and is actually commonly found in nature, like many have already said here. As you continue to zoom inwards into the fractal, you’ll see the same pattern over and over again. I think a visual aid will help you understand :rolleyes: :


(Link provided instead of directly showing. Its a large image and WILL slow down your web browser. Its 34.9 MB for those with limited data usage)

If you notice, you’ll see a bunch of tiny cubes in a hollow spherical area, and the same thing occurring in those cubes. I could zoom in as far as I’d like and continually see that pattern.
[/quote]
Not necessarily the same pattern, the Mandelbrot fractal and Julia set tend to have a huge variation in patterns.[/quote]I do suppose you’re right, Julia DOES get a bit crazy You can see the same base pattern in Mandelbrot quite easily though, even though the way it produces itself is based around one half of the fractal image.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

That is a very, very interesting article. I only ran my eyes over it though, I’ll read it in-depth later.

The strategy is based on its hypothesis that the universe follows a pattern: that it is populated by a hierarchy of similarly-shaped, electrically powered, spirals/loops such as galaxy clusters, galaxies, nebulae, stars, and smaller. Their shared features, all carrying tell-tale information, are on-record and available for interpretation. Initially six were found, promisingly pertinent to atoms: They are long-lived. They have angular momentum. They have torroidal magnetic fields. They are alternators/oscillators. They emit electromagnetic energy. They are flat. Signs of atomic fractality, including a positive feedback (oscillatory) mechanism, akin to the one found for celestial objects, are already apparent in atomic spectra: The wide-spectrum emissions of ions, the so-called “fine structure”, are a sure sign of such feedback in an over-driven oscillator, well-known to electronic engineers. The chaotic nature of the radiated frequencies is characteristic of fractals in that it is bifurcated.

You should read over that, it’s pretty interesting.

In a reply to your first paragraph about the quantum theory, I really haven’t went in depth into quantum physics myself. However, I do think that if the fractal is found in the atoms, I do believe it’ll be found in the quarks further inside.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:6, topic:450326”]I’ve always had an interest in fractals, they amaze me. The way they link nature with mathematics is just simply mindblowing.

In Scotland, our education system is absolutely horrid. When I was in high school, I brought fractal geometry into discussion in a physics class, and asked my teacher if it was true that when fractal geometry is applied to a physics state that no matter how far you zoom in on something you never reach a fundamental discrete or quantized level and she had no idea what fractals even were.

I still don’t even know the answer to that question, anyone care to shed some light on it? I’m currently doing a masters degree in physics and I don’t want to be the idiot who brings it up in a lecture or study group and is wrong.[/quote]

I don’t want to be wrong either, so I’ll try and find a source to back me up. I think in theory you’re right, because fractals recursively generate themselves to infinitely deep levels. I think as far as physical nature is concerned, you would see somewhat of a fractal as you zoom in on, say, an organism. There’s one organism, many tissues, many many cells, and within each cell, are many many many many molecules and within those are many atoms. When you look smaller, you’d see the subatomic particles or more that make up the protons, neutrons, and electrons. Getting any farther than that gets into quantum theory I haven’t learned enough about to comment on.

Ah, and I just found this: http://www.fractaluniverse.org/v2/?page_id=51

So that takes a perspective I haven’t considered. They are analyzing the wave lengths and wave behaviors of particles and comparing it to Shrodinger’s wave equation. They are considering the complexity of nature to be iterative, so within each iteration is a more complex “graph” (if you will) of the particles wave lengths and wave behaviors, casting a sort of fractal system. I just skimmed the article, so I might wrong in this paragraph.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman

@m1lkman wrote:

Makes one wonder what kind of universal secrets will be unlocked with math. It’s a really interesting subject.

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

I’ve always had an interest in fractals, they amaze me. The way they link nature with mathematics is just simply mindblowing.

In Scotland, our education system is absolutely horrid. When I was in high school, I brought fractal geometry into discussion in a physics class, and asked my teacher if it was true that when fractal geometry is applied to a physics state that no matter how far you zoom in on something you never reach a fundamental discrete or quantized level and she had no idea what fractals even were.

I still don’t even know the answer to that question, anyone care to shed some light on it? I’m currently doing a masters degree in physics and I don’t want to be the idiot who brings it up in a lecture or study group and is wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

Fractals are very nice, back in high school we had to do an oral exam in a specific subject, and because I’ve always been intrigued with fractals, the choice for me was quite easy.
The book I read went over simple fractals, like the Koch snowflake, and how they’re constructed.
There was also a section on the Mandelbrot fractal, but back at the time the matter regarding that was way above me, since they talked about a lot of thing i hadn’t learned yet.

[quote=“Taharok, post:2, topic:450326”]Fractals are immensely interesting. They play a huge aspect in mathematics and, like the article said, nature. It’s slightly related, but the fibonacci sequence can also be found all around nature and sometimes in the form of a fractal! Here are some pictures:

I don’t know about you, but that’s just really interesting to me lol. Fractals are also useful cryptography and encryption, along with so many other fields of science. I’ve been neglecting replying because there’s really so much to talk about with fractals it’s a bit overwhelming.[/quote]


This is a pretty cool video for anyone interested in the relation between Fibonacci and nature!

Also, according to a lecturer I had last year, the breeding of rabbits in pairs can be considered as a Fibonacci sequence as well, assuming the conditions are ideal.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

I saw the pics and thought of Fib.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

I’ve always found fractals simple, yet complex at once. Such a simple shape or formula can create an absolutely amazing image, and adding more formulas just adds to it. Fractals are some of the most amazing pieces of art and mathematics I’ve ever seen, and that more people should know about them. They really are amazing, and I wish people appreciated the fact that they are art.

And like Taharok said, fractals are found in nature too. Fractals truly are everywhere and most people don’t even realize it.

Read full topic

item.title: Fractals
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Fractals are immensely interesting. They play a huge aspect in mathematics and, like the article said, nature. It’s slightly related, but the fibonacci sequence can also be found all around nature and sometimes in the form of a fractal! Here are some pictures:

I don’t know about you, but that’s just really interesting to me lol. Fractals are also useful cryptography and encryption, along with so many other fields of science. I’ve been neglecting replying because there’s really so much to talk about with fractals it’s a bit overwhelming.

Read full topic
